key_insight: The paper introduces PoseBench, a standardized benchmark showing that modern deep‑learning docking and structure‑prediction methods can produce many accurate protein–ligand poses but retain systematic weaknesses in scoring, ranking, and generalization to novel complexes.
problem_solved: Addresses the lack of a comprehensive, reproducible benchmark to objectively assess strengths, failure modes, and real-world limits of AI‑based protein–ligand docking and structure‑prediction methods.
method: Assemble PoseBench: a curated, diverse dataset and standardized evaluation protocol for protein–ligand docking.
Systematically evaluate state‑of‑the‑art deep‑learning docking and structure‑prediction models across pose accuracy, scoring/ranking, and generalization metrics.
Analyze failure modes and quantify where models succeed versus where improvements (e.g., scoring, flexibility handling, out‑of‑distribution ligands) are needed.
impact: Provides AI/ML practitioners with a reproducible benchmark and diagnostic analysis to guide model development, prioritize improvements (scoring, robustness, generalization), and accelerate reliable AI‑driven docking in drug discovery.
visual_elements: Workflow diagram: PoseBench data curation → model evaluation → metrics/analysis
Bar chart: model comparison on pose‑accuracy thresholds (e.g., % within 2 Å RMSD)
Heatmap or matrix: failure modes by protein family and ligand class to show generalization gaps
Icon strip: quick takeaways highlighting strengths (pose prediction) vs weaknesses (scoring, ranking, OOD generalization)
paper_title: Assessing the potential of deep learning for protein–ligand docking
paper_authors: Alex Morehead, Nabin Giri, Jian Liu, Pawan Neupane, Jianlin Cheng
